Looking at the provided programs:

- Program 1: reads an integer N and N points, then outputs a double (average of all pairwise distances).

   // Step 1: Read input for the first program.
   int N;
   scanf("%d", &N);
   int (*pos)[2] = malloc(N * sizeof(int[2]));
   for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
        scanf("%d %d", &pos[i][0], &pos[i][1]);
   }

   // Compute the total distance
   double total = 0;
   for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
        for (int j = 0; j < N; j++) {
            if (i == j) continue;
            int dx = pos[i][0] - pos[j][0];
            int dy = pos[i][1] - pos[j][1];
            total += sqrt(dx*dx + dy*dy);
        }
   }
   double avg = total / N;

   // Round to nearest integer
   long long rounded_avg = (long long)round(avg);

   // Convert rounded_avg to a string (in base 10, normal order: most significant first)
   // We need to know the length. We can use snprintf to compute the length.
   char buffer1[100]; // large enough for 64-bit integer
   snprintf(buffer1, sizeof(buffer1), "%lld", rounded_avg);
   int len1 = strlen(buffer1);

   // Now, we need to create the digit array for the second program: in reverse order, and with an extra digit (and one more for safety).
   int *digits = calloc(len1+3, sizeof(int)); // indices 0 to len1+2, initialized to 0.
   // Reverse: the least significant digit (last char in buffer1) goes to index0.
   for (int i = 0; i < len1; i++) {
        digits[i] = buffer1[len1-1-i] - '0';
   }

   // Now run the second program's algorithm
   long long bills = 0;
   for (int i = 0; i <= len1; i++) { // we go to i=len1 (inclusive) because the array has len1 in the original, but we allocated extra.
        if (digits[i] == 10) {
            digits[i+1]++;
            digits[i] = 0;
        }
        if (digits[i] < 5) {
            bills += digits[i];
        } else if (digits[i] == 5) {
            if (digits[i+1] >= 5) {
                digits[i+1]++;
            }
            bills += 5;
        } else {
            digits[i+1]++;
            bills += 10 - digits[i];
        }
   }

   // Now, bills is the result of the second program (an integer).

   // Step for the third program: convert bills to a string (base 10)
   char buffer2[100];
   snprintf(buffer2, sizeof(buffer2), "%lld", bills);
   int len2 = strlen(buffer2);

   // Now, we have the string for the third program: buffer2.

   // We create two arrays (for the forward and backward pass) but we don't need to actually build the entire string, we can simulate the changes?
   // Alternatively, we can create two copies of the string and modify them.

   // We'll do two passes: 
   // Pass1: forward
   char *a = strdup(buffer2);
   int changes1 = 0;
   for (int i = 1; i < len2; i++) {
        if (a[i] == a[i-1]) {
            // flip a[i]: if it is '1' then '0', else '1'
            if (a[i] == '1') {
                a[i] = '0';
            } else {
                a[i] = '1';
            }
            changes1++;
        }
   }

   // Pass2: backward
   char *b = strdup(buffer2);
   int changes2 = 0;
   for (int i = len2-1; i > 0; i--) {
        if (b[i] == b[i-1]) {
            // flip b[i-1]
            if (b[i-1] == '1') {
                b[i-1] = '0';
            } else {
                b[i-1] = '1';
            }
            changes2++;
        }
   }

   int result = changes1 < changes2 ? changes1 : changes2;

   // Output the result
   printf("%d\n", result);

   // Free memory
   free(pos);
   free(digits);
   free(a);
   free(b);
